benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/tags - Retrieve account tags

covered: Valid Request: Multiple "happy path" scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05) validate successful retrieval with combinations of query parameters (includedDeleted, audit).
Empty Response: TC06 verifies the endpoint returns an empty JSON array when an account has no tags.
Query Parameters: Positive and negative tests for audit (FULL, MINIMAL, NONE) and includedDeleted are present (TC02–TC05, TC09, TC10).
Error handling: Invalid accountId format, partial/empty/whitespace accountId cases, and non-existent account are covered (TC07, TC08, TC20–TC22). 400/404 error scenarios from the story are addressed.
Authorization: Missing and invalid auth token scenarios are covered (TC12, TC13) which exercise unauthorized access handling.
Security: Injection and XSS input validation tests are included (TC14, TC15).
Performance & scale: High-volume and concurrency scenarios are present (TC16, TC17).
Resilience / integration: Downstream/unavailable service scenarios and service-unavailable/server errors are covered (TC11, TC24).
Regression & compatibility: Regression and legacy-client scenarios are present (TC18, TC19).
Response metadata: At least one scenario (TC01) asserts Content-Type application/json, and many tests implicitly validate response structure and presence/absence of audit/deleted tags.
gaps: Pagination: No tests exercise pagination (limit/offset or page) or partial retrieval — important for large datasets instead of returning huge arrays in one response.
Caching Behavior: No scenarios verify caching headers or conditional GET behavior (ETag/If-None-Match, Last-Modified, Cache-Control, 304 responses).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit tests for rate-limiting behavior (e.g., 429 responses, Retry-After), TC17 covers concurrency but not throttling limits.
Schema-level validation: Tests assert "JSON array of Tag objects" but do not validate Tag object schema fields, types, required properties, or enums against the API definitions.
Authorization nuance (403): Tests cover unauthenticated (401) but not forbidden/authorization-permissions (403) cases where authenticated users lack required permissions/roles.
Header consistency: Aside from one Content-Type check, there are no assertions across scenarios for other important headers (Content-Length, Cache-Control, ETag, request-id/correlation ids).

Pagination + Performance combination: The performance test (10,000 tags) expects a single payload; there are no tests that combine large datasets with pagination to verify server behavior and acceptable response sizes.

Edge-case query parameter behaviors: Missing tests for explicit includedDeleted=false, audit default behavior across multiple requests, case-sensitivity of query parameters, and URL-encoding of parameter values.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: limit/offset (or page/size) behavior, boundary values (page=0, page=last), and behavior when requesting pages beyond available data. Verify correct counts and links (if any).
Add caching and conditional GET tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers on 200 responses, and test If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since to expect 304 Not Modified when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: hammer the endpoint to observe throttling behavior, assert 429 responses and Retry-After header handling.

Add Tag schema validation tests: assert each Tag object contains required fields with correct types/values (id, name, createdDate, createdBy, audit fields when requested) and validate enums/UUID formats as appropriate.
Add authorization-permission tests (403): create authenticated users with insufficient permissions and assert 403 Forbidden is returned.

Replace or augment the single giant payload performance test with pagination-aware performance tests (e.g., request pages of size N and measure response times), and add streaming/partial response tests if supported.
Add more negative query-parameter tests: explicitly test includedDeleted=false, combined/malformed query strings, parameter case sensitivity, and URL-encoded inputs.

Standardize header assertions across scenarios: ensure Content-Type, Content-Length/Transfer-Encoding, and any correlation/request-id headers are present and correct in both success and error responses.
